nodes.body: Not ready to merge! Please only review.
Should I move `lemma match_xYz` to a different file, so that I can use `linarith` to make the proof shorter?
I'm going to golf this.
I don't think that naming lists `x₁` etc follows our naming conventions. Also please add a docstring.

> I'm going to golf this.

Wow, that was shortened much much much more than I expected!!
@eric-wieser What do you think about variable names here? Otherwise LGTM (I'm not merging because I wrote the current proof).
🚀 Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by YaelDillies.
bors r+

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7716423725/job/21033187389)
  * [Check all files imported](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7716423725/job/21033186713)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/7716423725/job/21033186909)

The names of the lists are a bit weird but nothing better comes to mind.

maintainer merge

The names of the lists are a bit weird but nothing better comes to mind.

maintainer merge
These don't strike me as good lemmas; the bar needs to be higher than "needs more than one existing lemma to prove", as that set is unbounded!
In my project about grammars (Lean 3) `length_append_append` is used 13 times and `reverse_append_append` is used 6 times. From my point of view, they reach the threshold of usefulness.

I think the analogous lemma I'm thinking of would be `op_mul_mul : op (a * b * c) = op c * op b * op a`, which mathlib also doesn't have (which I claim is evidence that we don't want to go down the road of adding this kind of lemma).
What is `op` in your example?
`MulOpposite.op`
I see your point.

My opinion is that in both cases, it should depend on the number of uses in mathlib in near future.

On one hand, these lemmata don't provide any value in the sense that anybody who would be able to use them also would be able to easily prove them themselves.

On the other hand, existence of these lemmata in my project makes my proofs shorter; and you are the first one who complains that my proofs are too long / not enough modular. If you forbid `List.length_append_append` et al., it will get even worse.
I'm happy to be overruled here by another reviewer
I think we should not have those lemmas. They are two very simple rewrites (actually, one very simple rewrite twice!) chained together.
They pop up very often when working with languages, not only in the `List.append_singleton_append_inj_of_nmem` proof. But of course, I can do everything without them if preferable.
It is preferable.

Also there are proofs with a state where `List.reverse_append` matches the goal in several places but `List.reverse_append_append` matches only one place in the goal, leading to a greater simplification when rewriting with the latter.
You can rewrite with `(reverse_append _ _).trans (congr_arg (· ++ _) $ reverse_append _ _)` if you want to.
OK removed.
This should conclude that `Y₁ = Y₂` too
You are right! Should the output of the lemma be a conjunction of three identities, or should there be three lemmata instead?
I think it should be a single lemma, phrased as an `Iff` (where the reverse direction is trivial)
That's a very smart idea, thanks!
Lemma names should not reference the names of their variables. This should be named something like `append_singleton_append_inj_of_nmem`
Thank you!
Can you write this as ` a < c ↔ b < d`?

```suggestion
  exact (add_lt_add_of_lt_of_le a_lt_c contr).ne total
```

Leading to the question:
* can you state this more generally than just for `Nat`?
* does mathlib already have that statement?

You can generalize it to one these two:
```
private lemma lt_iff_gt_of_eq_add
    {M : Type*} [LinearOrderedAddCommMonoid M] [CovariantClass M M (· + ·) (· < ·)]
    {a b c d : M} (total : a + b = c + d) :
    a < c ↔ d < b := by
  constructor
  · intro hac
    by_contra contr
    rw [not_lt] at contr
    exact (add_lt_add_of_lt_of_le hac contr).ne total
  · intro hbd
    by_contra contr
    rw [not_lt] at contr
    rw [add_comm a b, add_comm c d] at total
    exact (add_lt_add_of_lt_of_le hbd contr).ne total.symm

private lemma lt_iff_gt_of_eq_add' {M : Type*} [LinearOrderedSemiring M]
    {a b c d : M} (total : a + b = c + d) :
    a < c ↔ d < b :=
  lt_iff_gt_of_eq_add total
```
I didn't find them in Mathlib.
See new version.

This part of the name is inferrable.
```suggestion
lemma append_singleton_append_inj {x₁ x₂ z₁ z₂ : List α} {Y₁ Y₂ : α}
```
@eric-wieser chose the name.
It's quite confusing that the collections are lower-cased and the element upper-cased. If anything, I would have expected the exact opposite!
What naming do you suggest?

Something like this, maybe
```suggestion
lemma append_singleton_append_inj_of_nmem {x₁ x₂ z₁ z₂ : List α} {a₁ a₂ : α}
    (notin_x : a₂ ∉ x₁) (notin_z : a₂ ∉ z₁) :
    x₁ ++ [a₁] ++ z₁ = x₂ ++ [a₂] ++ z₂ ↔ x₁ = x₂ ∧ a₁ = a₂ ∧ z₁ = z₂ := by
```
I'm intrigued. Is there no easier proof by inducting on `x₁` generalising `x₂` and casing on `x₂`?
I am almost sure there exists an easier proof.

```suggestion
lemma append_cons_inj_of_not_mem {x₁ x₂ z₁ z₂ : List α} {a₁ a₂ : α}
```
and change the PR title too

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: List.append_cons_inj_of_not_mem
